page.title: 19Richard Cameron
page.content: One of the most important events in our past was the signing of the "Sanquhar Declaration". For 40 years the Covenanters had been fighting against the Stuart kings' attempts to unify religious practices and to introduce English Prayerbooks into Scottish churches, when on 22nd June 1680 a leading Covenanter, Richard Cameron, and 20 armed men rode into Sanquhar. At the town centre, Cameron nailed onto the market cross a declaration of war on King Charles II, naming him a tyrant and an enemy of Christ. This was seen as an act of treason and a reward of 5000 merks was offered for Cameron's arrest. He was soon captured and executed by dragoons 30 miles NW of Sanquhar. A monument marks the place where he fell and a street in Sanquhar bears his name, as does a famous Scottish regiment.
